column1: This class is ARTD 200, Art History Survey Part One, taught by Wunderlich in 2023. 5 pts. Contemporary Connection- develop an original idea and connect it to ancient history  ART CHALLENGE PROJECTS: Challenge 1: Stonehenge Students will create an accurate miniature version of Stonehenge using their choice of materials. Document it in a photograph and write a short explanation using textbook as reference. This challenge will help students gain tactile familiarity with post and lintel architecture and with the complex physical layout of a significant historical monument.  Challenge 2: Walk Like an Egyptian Students will consider Egyptian influences on contemporary visual culture. Image can be a found or created. Students document with photograph, provide written explanation with reference to textbook. Themes could include hieroglyphics, death rituals- mummification, etc. Challenge 3: GREEK WEEK Students will make comparisons and find connections between ancient Greek Civilization and contemporary culture- including traditions, language, or architecture. Document it with a photo and written explanation (including textbook reference).
column2: What is the first challenge?
column3: The first challenge is to create an accurate mini version of Stonehenge using their choice of materials and documenting it with a photograph and written explanation.

column2: What topics can be explored in the second challenge?
column3: The second challenge involves exploring Egyptian influences on contemporary visual culture, which could include hieroglyphics, death rituals, and mummification.

column1: This class is ARTD 200, Art History Survey Part One, taught by Wunderlich in 2023. 5 pts. Appropriate length (2 pages), well-developed paragraphs, edited- correct spelling, grammar, and punctuation. Rubric for Library /Special Collections: CHOOSE THREE WORKS OF ART, DIFFERING IN TIME PERIOD AND THEME. DESCRIBE EACH WORK OF ART (USE ART TERMINOLOGY), TIME PERIOD, AND MAKE A CONNECTION (Compare/Contrast) TO ART HISTORY STUDIES (textbook and lecture notes) (INCLUDE PAGE # REFERENCES) Rubric:  10 pts. Description of three works, varying time periods, using appropriate terminology. 10 pts. Make connections to Art History textbook, including comparison and contrast to works. Use specific page #s as references for each example.  Exams: You will have four exams during the semester, plus a FINAL EXAM. Each exam will have multiple choice and essay questions. The final exam will be comprehensive. Attendance at final is mandatory.  In Class Presentation/Paper/Bibliography: Each student will become an expert on work of art or architecture from a list provided by the instructor. All presentations will take place in class on the scheduled day. Students will give a 3-4 min. presentation. Students will accompany presentation with one-page paper of notes/ bibliography. A detailed rubric will be provided with specific criteria on Moodle.
column2: What are the requirements for the In Class Presentation/Paper/Bibliography?
column3: Presentation: 3-4 min, Paper: 1-page notes/bibliography; Rubric: provided on Moodle.

column1: This class is ARTD 200, Art History Survey Part One, taught by Wunderlich in 2023. III. Course Policies  Attendance Policy (Read Thoroughly: Attendance and Punctuality Are Mandatory):  Monmouth College policy states that you are required to attend classes. Attendance is required for the full time period each class. You may miss two (2) classes without penalty, although pop quizzes and participation points may be lost. The third absence begins to lower your final grade. Students who have five absences will receive a failing grade for the course. Even if you have valid reasons for missing class, it does not change the fact that you have missed out on participating in class activities and adding to the community experience. ** Tardies will affect your grade; two (2) tardies of more than ten minutes will count as one full absence. If you do miss class, email the instructor as to the reason for your absence. Certain circumstances will sometimes indicate a need for help from Student Support Services. If you miss a class, it will be your responsibility to find out what you missed. Fellow students, the syllabus, and Moodle lectures can be helpful resources. I encourage you to use office hours or email the instructor whenever you need assistance.
column2: What is the attendance policy?
column3: Students are required to attend all classes; absences and tardies are limited to two (2) with exceptions in special cases. Penalties begin to apply after 3 absences and if there are 5 absences the student will be given a failing grade. Tardies of more than 10 minutes also count towards the absences.

column1: This class is ARTD 200, Art History Survey Part One, taught by Wunderlich in 2023.  Policies on Academic Dishonesty: From the Monmouth College Academic Honesty Policy: We view academic dishonesty as a threat to the integrity and intellectual mission of our institution. Any breach of the academic honesty policy either intentionally or unintentionally - will be taken seriously and may result not only in failure in the course, but in suspension or expulsion from the college. It is each students responsibility to read, understand and comply with the general academic honesty policy at Monmouth College, as defined here in the Scots Guide, and to the specific guidelines for each course, as elaborated on the professors syllabus. The following areas are examples of violations of the academic honesty policy: Cheating on tests, labs, etc; Plagiarism, i.e., using the words, ideas, writing, or work of another without giving appropriate credit; Improper collaboration between students, i.e., not doing ones own work on outside assignments specified as group projects by the instructor;
column2: What is an example of cheating on tests, labs, etc?
column3: Copying another student's answers on a test or lab.

column1: This class is ARTD 200, Art History Survey Part One, taught by Wunderlich in 2023. Submitting work previously submitted in another course, without previous authorization by the instructor. Please note that this list is not intended to be exhaustive. The complete Monmouth College Academic Honesty Policy can be found on the College web page by clicking on Student Life then on Scots Guide in the navigation bar to the left, then Academic Regulations in the navigation bar at the left. Or you can visit the web page directly by typing in this URL:https://ou.monmouthcollege.edu/life/residence-life/scots-guide/academic-regulations.aspx In this course, any violation of the academic honesty policy will have varying consequences depending on the severity of the infraction as judged by the instructor. Minimally, a violation will result in an F or 0 points on the assignment in question. Additionally, the students course grade may be lowered by one letter grade. In severe cases, the student will be assigned a course grade of F and dismissed from the class. All cases of academic dishonesty will be reported to the Associate Dean who may decide to recommend further action to the Admissions and Academic Status Committee, including suspension or dismissal. It is assumed that students will educate themselves regarding what is considered to be academic dishonesty, so excuses or claims of ignorance will not mitigate the consequences of any violations.
column2: What is the Monmouth College Academic Honesty Policy?
column3: The Monmouth College Academic Honesty Policy outlines the expectations and consequences of academic dishonesty such as plagiarism and collusion.

column1: This class is ARTD 260, Intro to Handbuilding, taught by Wunderlich in 2021. Course objectives:  Students will:   Learn the fundamental principles of ceramics and develop technical skills for working in clay.   Be introduced to raw materials and composition of clay and glazes.   Be exposed to general history of ancient and contemporary ceramics.   Experience a variety of hand building and wheel thrown methods, and learn a variety of decorating, glazing, and firing techniques.   Develop sensitivity to formal aesthetic design and craftsmanship for both functional and non-functional ceramic forms.   Understand the value of maintaining a sketchbook for preliminary planning, ideas, and glazing and firing documentation.   Learn problem-solving skills associated with designing and creating three-dimensional art.   Become familiar with ceramic studio terminology.   Learn how to write, critique, and speak about art. Course Outcomes:  Students will:   Learn a variety of ways to create forms in clay, including pinch, coil, slab, extruding, press-molding, and wheel-throwing techniques.
column2: What are the course objectives?
column3: Students will learn the fundamental principles of ceramics and develop technical skills for working in clay; be introduced to raw materials and composition of clay and glazes; be exposed to general history of ancient and contemporary ceramics; experience a variety of hand building and wheel thrown methods; develop sensitivity to formal aesthetic design and craftsmanship for both functional and non-functional ceramic forms; understand the value of maintaining a sketchbook for preliminary planning, ideas, and glazing and firing documentation; learn problem-solving skills associated with designing and creating three-dimensional art; become familiar with ceramic studio terminology; and learn how to write, critique, and speak about art.

column1: This class is ARTD 260, Intro to Handbuilding, taught by Wunderlich in 2021. Art Department Program Goals: This course meets the following goals of the Art Dept.: Students will develop skills of media manipulation through a functional understanding of the physical properties of materials combined with rigorous practice with media-specific techniques and processes. Students will appreciate and explore the communicative and expressive powers of visual art through both the creation of personally meaningful artworks in studio courses and through the study of other artists and cultures in art history courses. Students will develop improved skills of creativity, innovation, and problem solving through engaged participation in the cognitive and physical processes of making art.  Students will learn strategies for the interpretation and criticism of works of art. Students will develop improved skills of oral, written, and visual communication through making, through critique processes, and through interpretation activities.  Students will understand research and creation processes distinct to the visual arts discipline.
column2: What skills will students develop in this program?
column3: Students will develop skills of media manipulation, appreciate and explore the communicative and expressive powers of visual art, improved skills of creativity, innovation, and problem solving, strategies for the interpretation and criticism of works of art, improved skills of oral, written, and visual communication, and understand research and creation processes distinct to the visual arts discipline.

column1: This class is ARTD 260, Intro to Handbuilding, taught by Wunderlich in 2021. Time Commitment and Work Expectations: This course requires a minimum of 4 to 5 hours outside of class per week, including time spent researching, designing, constructing, and glazing projects. You will also assist in studio duties such as pugging clay, mixing glazes, loading/unloading kilns, and cleaning the ceramics lab. Additionally, students will be required to attend field trips, gallery openings, and guest lectures outside of scheduled class times.  Ceramics 260 meets T/TH for approx. 3 hours each session = 6 hours per week.  6 in class 4 outside of class working on projects in ceramics lab 1 research preliminary planning 1 visits to art exhibitions/ gallery receptions _________________________ Total: approx. 12 hours a week  In Class Participation: This is a hands-on course. Please be prepared to be productive during the entire class period. Personal research, sketching, reading, and writing will be done outside of class. Please do not bring laptops, phones, or other sensitive tech items to class. No headphones permitted in ceramics room during class.
column2: What is the minimum number of hours required for this course each week?
column3: 12 hours.

column1: This class is ARTD 260, Intro to Handbuilding, taught by Wunderlich in 2021. Allergies: Please share any important allergy information with me, as we sometimes have treats! Required Course Tools and Materials:  Sketchbook (unlined/blank pages)  (Optional) Change of clothing or apron **You will get messy! Please dress accordingly. Closed-toed shoes  Pen / pencil Optional: Exacto knife, texture tools, stamps Tools: The ceramics studio provides clay tools for your use. All tools need to be washed and put away in their designated place after use and do not leave the Ceramics Lab. Students will have access to a cupboard to keep projects in. Some tools are sharp and require careful and responsible usage. Safety Expectations for the Classroom and Community All members of the campus community are required to WEAR A MASK AT ALL TIMES in all public spaces, including classrooms. Students are expected to self-monitor symptoms and self-quarantine when symptoms of COVID or other illness are present. If you are not able to attend class, please contact professor as a courtesy check-in. Please refer to the MC website for campus safety practices.
column2: What type of sketchbook to use for the course?
column3: Unlined/blank pages

column1: This class is ARTD 260, Intro to Handbuilding, taught by Wunderlich in 2021. Project Evaluation Criteria: Each project assigned explores a specific technique with particular goals. Students should do their best work for each project. While some classroom time will be allotted to working on projects, students are expected to spend several hours a week outside of class on projects and practicing techniques.   Preliminary planning in sketchbooks is essential. Students will be graded for comprehensive thought, research and analysis given to each project.   Students will give each project an original title, and students will be asked to verbalize or write about their research and process in a short reflection, also describing building and glazing techniques personal significance for each project.   Students are expected to be engaged in classroom discussions and demos, and to participate in clean up of Ceramics Lab, and in mixing clay and loading/unloading kilns. The last 15 minutes of every class period will be spent in clean up activities, identified by cleaning chart.
column2: What is the focus of each project?
column3: Each project assigned explores a specific technique with particular goals.

column1: This class is ARTD 260, Intro to Handbuilding, taught by Wunderlich in 2021.  Critiques are held at the conclusion of every project, and students are expected to participate. Students will discover their strengths and weaknesses, how their work can be improved, and how to evaluate and speak critically about art. It is imperative to complete projects on time and to participate in critiques. (ONLINE) FOUR PROJECTS PLUS FINAL EXAM SOCIAL MEDIA DOCUMENTATION PROJECT: Projects will be carefully evaluated, and receive incremental grading based on the following percentages:   Preliminary drawings, research, and plans in sketchbook   Specific parameters of the project are met (turned in on time, met height requirements, titled, etc.)   Quality of work, craftsmanship, attention to detail, neatness in execution, reflects appropriate time commitment   Originality of design, creativity, taking risks   Thoughtfulness of title, content, written reflection  Glaze surface- finished by deadline, complexity, design, and overall success of glaze surface TWO EXHIBITION RESPONSE PROJECTS:
column2: What is the format for critiques?
column3: Critiques are held at the conclusion of every project, and students are expected to participate.

column1: This class is ARTD 260, Intro to Handbuilding, taught by Wunderlich in 2021. Juried byCherry Galushua Simmons, 80 November 10 December 8 Reception: Friday, November 12th3:00-4:30 (Gallery talk at 3:30) STUDENTS ARE REQUIRED TO SUBMIT AT LEAST TWO WORKS IN THE STUDENT SHOW! *Attendance Policy Students are required to attend class for the full 3- hour lab period. It is important attend class as there are project introductions, demonstrations, and critiques on a regular basis. Missing more than two class periods will affect your grade. If you do miss class, you are responsible for coming in outside of class to make up for lost time. Please email the instructor as a courtesy if you are not able to attend class. FINAL EXAM: 12/13 8:00 am DOCUMENTATION OF CERAMIC PROJECTS- on social media Grading Policy: Grades are based on participation/classroom attitude and generosity, 2 gallery reflection objects, completion of 4 ceramic projects, and final exam documentation project.  Projects: 70 %  2 Written/Object Reflections 10%  Final Exam: Documentation presentation 10%  Participation, Daily Work Ethic, and Clean-up 10%
column2: What is the reception date for the student show?
column3: Friday, November 12th

column1: This class is ARTD 260, Intro to Handbuilding, taught by Wunderlich in 2021. Attitude: Students should demonstrate a positive attitude and spirit of generosity in our classroom community. THIS INCLUDES WEARING A MASK AT ALL TIMES as long as COVID guidelines apply. Access and Cleanliness: Students must clean up after themselves during class and after hours. Students who are enrolled in ceramics are permitted in the CERAMICS LAB after hours this semester. Please contact the instructor if you would like to bring a guest into the ceramics lab, and keep in mind that you need to ensure that their workspace is cleaned up. Please leave sufficient time to clean up, especially when using the wheels.  Academic Honesty: Students should not present any work completed by someone else as being their own work, nor should they present any plagiarized or copyrighted images, or work done in a previous art class. All work submitted by a student for a grade must be the product of the students, and only the students, efforts. Additionally, any website image used for inspiration must be clearly documented in the project.
column2: Can students access the ceramics lab after hours?
column3: Yes, students are permitted in the ceramics lab after hours this semester.

column1: This class is ARTD 260, Intro to Handbuilding, taught by Wunderlich in 2021. McMike After-Hours Policy: Students are reminded of the following rules in McMichael Academic:   Do not prop doors open   Do not let others into the ceramics lab unless they are in ceramics class  Do not give your card to anyone else. It is a violation of the College policy.   No drugs or alcohol is allowed in the building. Violators will be referred to the Office of Residence Life for disciplinary action.  When you swipe your key card an electronic record is created, so we know who has accessed the building. You will be held responsible for the actions of other students that are let into the building with your key card.  Classroom projectors/computers are for faculty use only. Watching movies is not permitted (without express written permission from an art professor).  Key card access means that you are obligated to report suspicious activity. Report all suspicious activity immediately to the following phone number: Monmouth College Security: 309-337-5708 Monmouth College Emergency Phone: 309-337-5713
column2: Is it allowed to prop doors open?
column3: No, it is not allowed to prop doors open.

column1: This class is ARTD 260, Intro to Handbuilding, taught by Wunderlich in 2021. Phones/Tech Devices POLICY: Phones and clay do not work well together. No headphones in class, no cell phone use in class except for usage approved by the instructor. column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Course Content:  This course is an introduction to wheel-thrown and hand-built forms in clay, with emphasis on functionality. Students will learn a variety of ceramic building and glazing techniques, design principles, and historical and cultural context for ceramic forms. Students will build a series of projects following this progression: preliminary planning and trouble-shooting in sketchbook, construction of form, drying, firing, glaze application, glaze firing, final critique, written evaluation, and documentation.  Course objectives:  Students will:  Learn the fundamental principles of ceramics and develop technical skills for working in clay.   Be introduced to raw materials and composition of clay and glazes.   Be exposed to general history of ancient and contemporary ceramics. Experience a variety of hand building and wheel thrown methods, and learn a variety of decorating, glazing, and firing techniques. Develop sensitivity to formal aesthetic design and craftsmanship for both functional and non-functional ceramic forms.
column2: What techniques will be covered in this course?
column3: Hand building and wheel thrown methods, glazing, and firing techniques.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Understand the value of maintaining a sketchbook for preliminary planning, ideas, and glazing and firing documentation. Learn problem-solving skills associated with designing and creating three-dimensional art. Become familiar with ceramic studio terminology. Learn how to write, critique, and speak about art. Learn basic photo/video documentation for three-dimensional objects. Course Outcomes: Students will: Learn a variety of ways to create forms in clay, including pinch, coil, slab, extruding, press-molding, wheel-throwing and altering techniques. Learn to be problem solvers in addressing technical issues such as uneven drying, cracking, and shrinkage. Be able to apply glazes correctly to create an appealing and appropriate surface. Be able to think and speak critically about their works of art and connect them to the greater context of historical and contemporary art. Begin to establish and utilize a unique visual vocabulary that includes individual cultural, academic, or personal references, passions, and symbolism.
column2: What techniques of ceramics can I learn in this course?
column3: Pinch, coil, slab, extruding, press-molding, wheel-throwing and altering techniques.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Gain experience in the process of visualizing three-dimensional art, including preliminary design, research, construction with tactile materials, firing, glazing, critical self- and peer- evaluation, and documentation.  Beauty and Meaning Course: The credit you earn in this course counts towards your General Beauty and Meaning Requirement for graduation. Beauty and Meaning Course Goals:  1. Students will learn and apply strategies for engaging with works of art. 2. Students will explore the dynamic relationships that exist between arts and cultures. 3. Students will explore how people make meaning through creating or engaging with works of art. 4. Students will understand artistic processes. Time Commitment and Work Expectations: This course requires a minimum of 4 hours outside of class per week, including time doing research, design, and preliminary planning for projects, construction of forms (on the wheel and/or by hand, texturing, detailing, altering), applying glazes and clean-up. Additionally, students will be required to view and respond to online content and visit the campus art gallery (located on the upper level of Hewes Library). Students may also be required to assist in studio duties such as pugging clay.
column2: What is the time commitment for this course?
column3: A minimum of 4 hours outside of class per week are required for the course.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Ceramics 261 meets T/TH for approx. 3 hours each session = (You will be IN CLASS for 3 hours a week. You will be responsible to make up and document the additional 3 hours every week).  6 HRS. (3 in class, 3 outside of class during open studio times) 2-3 HRS. additional hours of work-time for projects in ceramics lab 2 HRS. design, planning, research, visiting Everett Gallery, writing papers and evaluations, viewing online content Total: Plan to devote approx. 10-11 hours a week to ceramics. In Class Participation: This is a hands-on course. Please be prepared to be productive during the entire class period. Personal research, sketching, reading, and writing will be done outside of class. Please do not bring laptops, phones, or other sensitive technological devices to class. If you are unable to attend class on your assigned day, please email the instructor to make alternative arrangements.  TO ACCOMMODATE SAFE-DISTANCING DURING PANDEMIC: For the first two weeks of Class we will be split into TWO GROUPS: Group A meets Tuesdays and Group B meets Thursdays. This means that you are in class with instructions only one day per week, which means that you will need to make up the 3 hours per week of class time by coming in during non-class hours. Instructor will post hours when she is available in the Lab for one-on-one guidance. * NO MORE THAN 8 people in the Ceramics Lab at one time.* If you are in quarantine or must go online during the semester, notify the instructor ASAP. You will have access to a CLAY BUCKET with supplies, clay, spray bottle, plastic- materials you can use to work in your dorm or at home.
column2: What groupings will the course follow to accommodate safe-distancing during the pandemic?
column3: For the first two weeks of Class, the course will be split into two groups: Group A meets Tuesdays and Group B meets Thursdays.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Ceramics 261 meets T/TH for approx. 3 hours each session = (You will be IN CLASS for 3 hours a week. You will be responsible to make up and document the additional 3 hours every week).  6 HRS. (3 in class, 3 outside of class during open studio times) 2-3 HRS. additional hours of work-time for projects in ceramics lab 2 HRS. design, planning, research, visiting Everett Gallery, writing papers and evaluations, viewing online content Total: Plan to devote approx. 10-11 hours a week to ceramics. In Class Participation: This is a hands-on course. Please be prepared to be productive during the entire class period. Personal research, sketching, reading, and writing will be done outside of class. Please do not bring laptops, phones, or other sensitive technological devices to class. If you are unable to attend class on your assigned day, please email the instructor to make alternative arrangements. column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Headphones/cellphones: Exposure to clay and water can damage phones, so exercise caution if you choose to use your electronic devices. Absolutely no headphones permitted in ceramics room during class time, as building a community through conversation and critical discussion is an extremely important part of the learning environment. Allergies: Please share any important allergy information with instructor. Project Evaluation Criteria: Each project assigned explores a specific technique with particular goals. Students should do the best possible work they can for each project. While classroom time will be given for working on projects, students are expected to spend several hours a week outside of class on projects.  Preliminary planning, research, and design trouble-shooting in sketchbooks is essential.  Students are expected to be engaged in classroom discussions and demos, and to participate in clean-up of work areas in Ceramics Lab. May be required to pug clay. Critiques are held at the conclusion of every major project, and students are expected to participate by discussing strengths and weaknesses of their projects and those of their peers. Analyzing, writing, and speaking are all components of the critique process. It is important to complete projects on time, attend and participate in critiques, and complete self-evaluation forms.
column2: Does using headphones in the ceramics room violate policy?
column3: Yes

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Criteria for evaluation:  Following the specific parameters given for that particular project  Quality of work, craftsmanship, attention to detail, neatness in execution  Originality of design, creativity, taking risks *  Preliminary drawings, research, and plans in sketchbook  Finished glaze surface  Project turned in on time, critique participation, written self-evaluation  Project is documented via photos or social media posts Attendance Policy: Attendance is Mandatory Monmouth College policy states that you are required to attend classes. Ceramics is a lab-based, tactile learning experience. Attendance is required for the full time period. If a student is tardy, leaves class early or has unexcused absences, it will negatively effect final grade. It is important to attend class when there are demos and critiques. If you have a valid reason for missing class such showing signs of illness, please discuss with the instructor via email. If you are in quarantine but feeling well, please arrange pickup of a clay bucket. Certain circumstances may qualify for help from Student Support Services. Anything you miss in class due to an absence is your responsibility to make up. It is your responsibility to obtain all missed instruction and information from fellow students and/or instructor.
column2: How can I make up for a class I have missed?
column3: You are responsible for obtaining all missed instruction and information from fellow students and/or instructor and making up any missed work.

column2: What is the Ceramics attendance policy at Monmouth College?
column3: Attendance is Mandatory. Ceramics is a lab-based, tactile learning experience and attendance is required for the full time period.

column2: What is part of the criteria for evaluation in a Ceramics project?
column3: Quality of work, craftsmanship, attention to detail, neatness in execution, originality of design, creativity, taking risks, preliminary drawings, research, and plans in sketchbook, finished glaze surface, project turned in on time, critique participation, written self-evaluation, project documented.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Exhibitions located in the EVERETT GALLERY, UPPER LEVEL of Hewes Library. You need to refer to LIBRARY HOURS to access exhibitions. Emergence Janis Mars Wunderlich January 11 February 11 Reception: Friday, February 11th3:00-4:30 (Gallery talk at 3:30) Next Skate...All Skate. Stacy Lotz February 21 April 1 Reception: Friday, March 25th3:00-4:30 (Gallery talk at 3:30) Attitude:  Students need to have a positive attitude in class, and come to class prepared. Students are required to clean up after themselves and be respectful citizens in our classroom community.  McMike After-Hours Policy: Students are reminded of the following rules in McMichael Academic:  Do not prop doors open  Do not let others into the building unless they are with you and you are responsible for them.  Do not give your card to anyone else. It is a violation of the College policy.  No drugs or alcohol is allowed in the building. Violators will be referred to the Office of Residence Life for disciplinary action.  When you swipe your key card an electronic record is created, so we know who has accessed the building. You will be held responsible for the actions of other students that are let into the building with your key card. Classroom projectors/computers are for faculty use only. Watching movies is not permitted (without express written permission from an art professor).
column2: What does the EVERETT GALLERY feature?
column3: The EVERETT GALLERY features exhibitions such as Emergence Janis Mars Wunderlich and Next Skate...All Skate. Stacy Lotz.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Key card access means that you are obligated to report suspicious activity. Report all suspicious activity immediately to the following phone numbers: Monmouth College Security: 309-337-5708 Monmouth College Emergency Phone: 309-337-5713  Building Policies / Safe Studio Practices: When you work outside of class, bring your own entertainment. In all rooms, projectors are foruse by faculty only. Dont use the projectors to watch movies while you work, and dont turn on the projectors to have access to the speakers so you can play music.  Always choose non-toxic options. Dont use oil-based or other toxic materials (waxes, wood stains, varnishes, etc) without permission of a faculty member and specific training on safety (skin protection, eye protection, air-quality considerations) and clean up. Go outside if you need to use an aerosol spray (including spray paint, spray fixative [or hairspray], or spray adhesive). Aerosols shouldnt be sprayed inside the building. When you are sanding or using other dusty materials (dry clay) consider the air quality for yourself and for others in the building. Minimize dust in the air.
column2: What phone number should I call to report suspicious activity?
column3: Monmouth College Security: 309-337-5708; Monmouth College Emergency Phone: 309-337-5713

column2: What materials need to be used outside of the building?

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. All art studios can have harmful chemicals in the air an on the surfaces. When you take a break to eat, wash your hands. If you borrow a tool or material from another room, return it exactly to where you got it from when you are done using it (duringthatwork session if you need to borrow it again each day, then do so). Wash and set aside to dry, any brushes, painting cups, palettes, etc. Please dont leave things in the sinks. Always clean up after yourself. Wipe off the table; sweep the floor; push in your chair. These things help keep our building a nice place to work. **This syllabus may change throughout the semester. The professor will alert students to any changes via moodle and in-class. column2: What do I need to do when I take a break to eat?
column3: Wash your hands.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Students will learn:  Throwing on the wheel-cylinder forms Pulling/building and attaching handles Shaping forms on the wheel Design and function principles related to cups, sets Adding narrative/personal meaning to cup forms Historical context for wheel thrown pottery- Mesopotamian, Egyptian, and Greek Civilizations Adding TEXT (via inscription, sgraffito, or decal) to surface PLATES, PLATTERS Project Goals: (set of 2) (4 small, 2 dinner sized, or one platter- large) Students will learn: Throwing plates, platters and horizontal forms on wheel Importance of compression of horizontal surfaces Decorative techniques such as sgraffito  Hand-building platters using slabs and slump molds Use of tools including slab-roller, extruder, plaster molds Trimming plates and platters THROWN AND ALTERED FORMS- TEAPOTS Project Goals: Students will learn: How to build multiple parts and assemble using additive and subtractive methods, slipping and scoring How to cut into and manipulate thrown and hand-built forms
column2: What is the historical context of wheel thrown pottery?
column3: Wheel thrown pottery is associated with Mesopotamian, Egyptian and Greek Civilizations.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Students will learn:  Throwing on the wheel-cylinder forms Pulling/building and attaching handles Shaping forms on the wheel Design and function principles related to cups, sets Adding narrative/personal meaning to cup forms Historical context for wheel thrown pottery- Mesopotamian, Egyptian, and Greek Civilizations Adding TEXT (via inscription, sgraffito, or decal) to surface PLATES, PLATTERS Project Goals: (set of 2) (4 small, 2 dinner sized, or one platter- large) Students will learn: Throwing plates, platters and horizontal forms on wheel Importance of compression of horizontal surfaces Decorative techniques such as sgraffito  Hand-building platters using slabs and slump molds Use of tools including slab-roller, extruder, plaster molds Trimming plates and platters THROWN AND ALTERED FORMS- TEAPOTS Project Goals: Students will learn: How to build multiple parts and assemble using additive and subtractive methods, slipping and scoring How to cut into and manipulate thrown and hand-built forms
column2: What is the project goal for plates, platters?
column3: The project goal for plates, platters is to create a set of 4 small, 2 dinner sized, or one platter-large.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Students will learn:  Throwing on the wheel-cylinder forms Pulling/building and attaching handles Shaping forms on the wheel Design and function principles related to cups, sets Adding narrative/personal meaning to cup forms Historical context for wheel thrown pottery- Mesopotamian, Egyptian, and Greek Civilizations Adding TEXT (via inscription, sgraffito, or decal) to surface PLATES, PLATTERS Project Goals: (set of 2) (4 small, 2 dinner sized, or one platter- large) Students will learn: Throwing plates, platters and horizontal forms on wheel Importance of compression of horizontal surfaces Decorative techniques such as sgraffito  Hand-building platters using slabs and slump molds Use of tools including slab-roller, extruder, plaster molds Trimming plates and platters THROWN AND ALTERED FORMS- TEAPOTS Project Goals: Students will learn: How to build multiple parts and assemble using additive and subtractive methods, slipping and scoring How to cut into and manipulate thrown and hand-built forms
column2: What techniques are used in thrown and altered forms- teapots?
column3: Techniques used in thrown and altered forms- teapots include building multiple parts and assembling using additive and subtractive methods, slipping and scoring, cutting into and manipulating thrown and hand-built forms, creative and thoughtful handle designs, using Plunge, coil and block methods.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Design principles in relation to multiple parts on a 3D form Making lids, spouts, handles, and other parts Throwing off the hump Learn about historical importance and visual differences of traditional teapot forms (Chinese, Japanese, American) Visual practice of elements and principles of design  MONUMENTAL-STACKED FORMS Project Goals: Students will learn: Strategies for Throwing with large amounts of clay-  Clay shrinkage Strategies for measuring objects that fit together GALLERY OBJECTS- WRITTEN RESPONSE Project Goals: Students will learn: The experience of going to an art exhibition at an art gallery How to analyze and write about art using appropriate terminology How to turn inspiration into ceramic form and glaze surface Connect exhibition to art historical or other contexts Gain appreciation for the vision and art of others Learn how to look carefully and critically at art objects FINAL EXAM- SOCIA MEDIA AND PHOTO/VIDEO DOCUMENTATION Project Goal: Students will learn: How to photograph 3D forms using proper lighting and background
column2: techniques How to video your work and techniques for editing down video into a short clip for showcasing Learning how to use social media for marketing and connecting with other artists  What are project goals for the Monumental-Stacked Forms project?
column3: Students will learn strategies for throwing with large amounts of clay, strategies for measuring objects that fit together, and clay shrinkage.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Design principles in relation to multiple parts on a 3D form Making lids, spouts, handles, and other parts Throwing off the hump Learn about historical importance and visual differences of traditional teapot forms (Chinese, Japanese, American) Visual practice of elements and principles of design  MONUMENTAL-STACKED FORMS Project Goals: Students will learn: Strategies for Throwing with large amounts of clay-  Clay shrinkage Strategies for measuring objects that fit together GALLERY OBJECTS- WRITTEN RESPONSE Project Goals: Students will learn: The experience of going to an art exhibition at an art gallery How to analyze and write about art using appropriate terminology How to turn inspiration into ceramic form and glaze surface Connect exhibition to art historical or other contexts Gain appreciation for the vision and art of others Learn how to look carefully and critically at art objects FINAL EXAM- SOCIA MEDIA AND PHOTO/VIDEO DOCUMENTATION Project Goal: Students will learn: How to photograph 3D forms using proper lighting and background
column2: What are project goals for the Gallery Objects-Written Response project?
column3: Students will learn the experience of attending an art exhibition, how to analyze and write about art, how to turn inspiration into ceramic form and glaze surface, the connection between the exhibition and art historical or other contexts, gain appreciation for the vision of and art of others, and learn to look carefully and critically at art objects.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Design principles in relation to multiple parts on a 3D form Making lids, spouts, handles, and other parts Throwing off the hump Learn about historical importance and visual differences of traditional teapot forms (Chinese, Japanese, American) Visual practice of elements and principles of design  MONUMENTAL-STACKED FORMS Project Goals: Students will learn: Strategies for Throwing with large amounts of clay-  Clay shrinkage Strategies for measuring objects that fit together GALLERY OBJECTS- WRITTEN RESPONSE Project Goals: Students will learn: The experience of going to an art exhibition at an art gallery How to analyze and write about art using appropriate terminology How to turn inspiration into ceramic form and glaze surface Connect exhibition to art historical or other contexts Gain appreciation for the vision and art of others Learn how to look carefully and critically at art objects FINAL EXAM- SOCIA MEDIA AND PHOTO/VIDEO DOCUMENTATION Project Goal: Students will learn: How to photograph 3D forms using proper lighting and background
column2: What are project goals for the Final Exam- Social Media and Photo/Video Documentation project?
column3: Students will learn how to photograph 3D forms, video their work and techniques for editing, use social media for marketing, and connecting with other artists.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. The impact of social media on artists How to create and edit short videos All Projects *Your projects should reflect individual work, unique to you and created by you. Please do not copy identical images from pinterest or other internet sites. Some projects require you to borrow concepts or forms from historic and contemporary ceramics, but do not replicate or create exact copies. Please be respectful of copyrights and visual plagiarism. *It is expected that all projects will be turned in on time. If you will miss the due date and critique, please make arrangements with the teacher ahead of time. If you are doing something extraordinary that requires extra time beyond the due date, talk with the teacher about an extension. *It is expected that students will apply surface details and treatments to the projects. In many cases this is done after the initial critique, but the expectation is that each project will be seen through to the end with a carefully applied surface. There is a final surface/glazing grade for each assignment.
column2: What are the consequences for plagiarism in the classroom?
column3: Plagiarism may result in disciplinary action including but not limited to loss of grades, being expelled from the class, and possibly the revocation of credentials.

column3: Speak to the teacher beforehand and make arrangements for an extension if the project requires more time.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. *All projects begin as sketches, designs and ideas in your sketchbook.  *All projects must have a title, created by you, and you are expected to speak about your work. All students need to participate during Critiques. *While you are given some work time in class, it is expected that you will spend several hours outside of class in practicing techniques and creating your projects. Enrolled students have extended access to the ceramics room. You should plan to spend up to 10-12 hours outside of class time each week. Attendance policy: YOU SHOULD NEVER MISS CLASS since you are only able to come once a week. IF YOU NEED TO SWITCH DAYS OR MISS CLASS, discuss with instructor. TARDIES and absences affect your ability to participate and will lower your final grade. IF YOU NEED TO MISS DUE TO PANDEMIC RELATED CIRCUMSTANCES- consult with instructor about getting a CERAMIC BUCKET KIT to work while you are isolating. NOTICES FROM THE COLLEGE Student Success at Monmouth College: Student Success & Accessibility Services offers FREE resources to assist Monmouth College students with their academic success. Programs include Supplemental Instruction for select classes, Drop-In and appointment tutoring, and individual Academic Coaching. Our office is here to help all students excel academically, since all students can work toward better grades, practice stronger study skills, and manage their time better.
column2: What is the attendance policy?
column3: You should never miss class and if you need to switch days or miss class you should discuss this with the instructor. Tardies and absences will lower your final grade. If you need to miss due to pandemic related circumstances, consult with your instructor about getting a ceramic bucket kit to work with while you are isolating.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. *All projects begin as sketches, designs and ideas in your sketchbook.  *All projects must have a title, created by you, and you are expected to speak about your work. All students need to participate during Critiques. *While you are given some work time in class, it is expected that you will spend several hours outside of class in practicing techniques and creating your projects. Enrolled students have extended access to the ceramics room. You should plan to spend up to 10-12 hours outside of class time each week. Attendance policy: YOU SHOULD NEVER MISS CLASS since you are only able to come once a week. IF YOU NEED TO SWITCH DAYS OR MISS CLASS, discuss with instructor. TARDIES and absences affect your ability to participate and will lower your final grade. IF YOU NEED TO MISS DUE TO PANDEMIC RELATED CIRCUMSTANCES- consult with instructor about getting a CERAMIC BUCKET KIT to work while you are isolating. Programs include Supplemental Instruction for select classes, Drop-In and appointment tutoring, and individual Academic Coaching. Our office is here to help all students excel academically, since all students can work toward better grades, practice stronger study skills, and manage their time better.
column2: How much time outside of class is expected for this project?
column3: It is expected that you will spend several hours outside of class in practicing techniques and creating your projects and you should plan to spend up to 10-12 hours outside of class time each week.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. The following areas are examples of violations of the academic honesty policy: Cheating on tests, labs, etc; Plagiarism, i.e., using the words, ideas, writing, or work of another without giving appropriate credit; Improper collaboration between students, i.e., not doing ones own work on outside assignments specified as group projects by the instructor; Submitting work previously submitted in another course, without previous authorization by the instructor. Please note that the listing above is not exhaustive. The complete Monmouth College Academic Honesty Policy can be found on the College web page by clicking on Student Life then on Scots Guide in the navigation bar to the left, then Academic Regulations in the navigation bar at the left. Or you can visit the web page directly by typing in this URL: http://department.monm.edu/stuserv/student-handbook/academic.htm. It is assumed that students will educate themselves regarding what is considered to be academic dishonesty, so excuses or claims of ignorance will not mitigate the consequences of any violations. Consult the instructor immediately if you have any questions, concerns, or even the slightest hesitation related to academic honesty.
column2: What are some examples of violations of the academic honesty policy?
column3: Cheating on tests, labs, etc; Plagiarism; Improper collaboration between students; and submitting work previously submitted in another course without authorization.

column1: This class is ARTD 261, Wheel-Throwin Ceramics, taught by Wunderlich in 2022. Violation of the academic honesty policy has varying consequences; these consequences correspond to the severity of the infraction, as judged by the instructor. Minimally, a violation will result in 0 points earned on the assignment in question. Severe infractions will result in the students dismissal from the class and a resulting grade of F. All cases of academic dishonesty will be reported to the Associate Dean, who may recommend to the Admissions and Academic Status Committee further action, including suspension or dismissal from Monmouth College. It is assumed that students will educate themselves regarding what is considered to be academic dishonesty, so excuses or claims of ignorance will not mitigate the consequences of any violations.
column2: What is the minimum consequence for a violation of the academic honesty policy?
column3: 0 points earned for the assignment in question.

column1: This class is ARTD 325, Junior Critique, taught by Wunderlich in 2023. YOUR STUDIO HOURS- _________________________________________________________________ Attendance:  Consider attendance mandatory. The quality of your work depends on your understanding of the readings and on-going class discussions. Each absence and tardiness will affect your final grade.  Grading:   Grading is based on the 3 assigned thematic projects, 3 critiques, class discussion correlating to the readings, written tickets and other written assignments, and a final exam of portfolio documentation. Additionally, students are required to develop a resume, career plan, and enter either an exhibition outside of campus during the semester or apply for an internship. Artwork: 40% 3 assigned, thematic works created through sketchbook and maquette building, along with 3 individual works dedicated to the shared critique. Artworks should show evidence of thoughtful engagement with the concepts and ideas that form the intention of the work, dedication to careful and focused use of materials, and commitment to achieving a high-level of visual quality though the purposeful use of the elements of art and the principles of composition. You will be expected to show weekly progress and problem- solving as actively documented in your sketchbook.
column2: How important is attendance in the studio?
column3: Attendance is important and mandatory, since class discussions and understanding the readings are necessary for the quality of the work done.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020. Required Texts Required means required. Points will be deducted from your lab grade if you do not have the photographic atlas by the second lab meeting.  Lecture text: Urry, L. A., Cain, M. L., Wasserman, S. A., Minorsky, P.V., Reece, J. B. & N. A. Campbell.  2016. Campbell Biology. 11th Edition. Benjamin Cummings, 1263 pp. ISBN-13-978013409341. Lab manual: Van De Graaff, K. M. and J. L. Crawley. 2018. Van De Graaffs Photographic Atlas for the Biology Laboratory. 8th Edition. Morton Publishing, 280 pp. ISBN-9781617317651. Lab sketchbook: Strathmore (or other) drawing paper sketch book, at least 24 sheets, and pencils, plain or colored. Grading Scale Assignment    Possible points A  90% A- 88 B+ 86  B 80  B- 78  C+ 76  C 70    C- 68 D+ 66 Lecture exams (3 x 100) 300  Add of difference between the lowest score and  the average of the three highest exams. Final exam (comprehensive)  200 Homework & reading quizzes  200 Lab quizzes (12; drop lowest 2; 10 x 25)  250 Lab Sketchbook  50 D 60 Total points possible
column2: What is the textbook for this class?
column3: Urry, L. A., Cain, M. L., Wasserman, S. A., Minorsky, P.V., Reece, J. B. & N. A. Campbell. 2016. Campbell Biology. 11th Edition. Benjamin Cummings, 1263 pp. ISBN-13-978013409341

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020.    1000 D- 58  Extra Credit: Occasionally I will offer extra credit opportunities to the entire class when I feel it will help meet learning objectives. Extra credit is not offered for individual students on a case by case basis.  What grades mean: The average high school student has a 3.0 GPA, which means the average high school student is deemed above average. I find this problematic. In my courses, I try to stick with the original meanings of the five letter grades: A = Excellence, B = Above average, C = Average, D = Below Average, F = Fail. Grades are a way of measuring you with respect to others, an unfortunate classification that will dog you your entire life! You might as well get used to being average in some respects, above average in others, and below average in still others just like all of us, even your professors. Grades are not a designation of your worth or value as a human being! Try not to overemphasize their significance.  IMPORTANT GUIDELINES and RULES Every social interaction is governed by rules. Most are unwritten, but in an interaction that is new to one or more of the parties (the student-college professor relationship may be relatively new to you), it helps to write things down so everyone understands their rights and responsibilities. Like a business contract, it establishes the responsibilities of each party toward the other. These guidelines and rules are designed in a spirit of mutual respect to help you succeed, and to help me help you succeed.
column2: What is the average GPA?

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020.    1000 D- 58  Extra Credit: Occasionally I will offer extra credit opportunities to the entire class when I feel it will help meet learning objectives. Extra credit is not offered for individual students on a case by case basis.  What grades mean: The average high school student has a 3.0 GPA, which means the average high school student is deemed above average. I find this problematic. In my courses, I try to stick with the original meanings of the five letter grades: A = Excellence, B = Above average, C = Average, D = Below Average, F = Fail. Grades are a way of measuring you with respect to others, an unfortunate classification that will dog you your entire life! You might as well get used to being average in some respects, above average in others, and below average in still others just like all of us, even your professors. Grades are not a designation of your worth or value as a human being! Try not to overemphasize their significance.  IMPORTANT GUIDELINES and RULES Every social interaction is governed by rules. Most are unwritten, but in an interaction that is new to one or more of the parties (the student-college professor relationship may be relatively new to you), it helps to write things down so everyone understands their rights and responsibilities. Like a business contract, it establishes the responsibilities of each party toward the other. These guidelines and rules are designed in a spirit of mutual respect to help you succeed, and to help me help you succeed.
column2: What is the importance of setting guidelines and rules?
column3: To ensure mutual respect and understanding of the student-teacher relationship.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020. Communication Outside of class, I will use e-mail to communicate with you. You should check your e-mail daily for important messages and reminders regarding homework, due dates, etc.  MOODLE will also be an important resource. Course materials such as: syllabus, schedules and other materials handed out on the first day of class; PowerPoint presentations from lab and lecture; all labs (there is no lab book, just the photographic atlas); homework, etc. Make use of the resources available on-line from your lecture textbook, Campbell Biology at masteringbio.com. Videos here can be especially helpful in understanding some concepts and processes. Policies for Absences and Make-up Exams Attendance is vital to your success in BIOL 155. More than two or three absences a semester will markedly affect your grade. If you miss lectures, you miss information that will be on tests. Getting this information second-hand from someone else who takes notes for you is much less effective than attending yourself. Thus, you should miss only for unavoidable reasons such as illness. If you are absent, you are responsible for obtaining notes to missed lectures from another student. I cannot recreate a lecture for you if you ask me what did I miss? If you missed class for a legitimate reason (e.g. illness) I will gladly take some time to go over the notes you have obtained from a classmate for the missed class.
column2: How can I stay informed about important information regarding homework and due dates?
column3: Check your e-mail daily.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020. In-class behavior. Your behavior in lecture and lab should be consistent with promoting a positive learning environment. That means that any behavior that interferes with my ability to teach or your or your classmates abilities to learn is prohibited. Disrespectful behavior not only interferes with my ability to teach, it is also demonstrates a lack of common courtesy. Some examples of prohibited behaviors (not a complete list): talking excessively (unless asking a relevant question or working in groups), texting, sleeping, listening to headphones, doing homework for another class, etc. Cell phones should be turned off and out of sight (not in your lap, where I can easily see them). Better yet, just dont bring them with you or turn them off and stow them in your book bag. If you distract me with cell phone use, I may confiscate your phone and retain it for up to 24 hours. Respect our 50-minute periods together as a sacred time for biology only. You will be better able to focus and learn!
column2: What are some examples of prohibited behaviors in-class?
column3: Talking excessively, texting, sleeping, listening to headphones, doing homework for another class, etc.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020. Lecture exams. If you know in advance that you will be unable to attend a scheduled exam due to an emergency or illness, please observe the following:  1) Notify me before the exam. This is common courtesy, so I can plan for your absence and the need for a makeup exam. You can notify me easily by calling my office (457-2394) or the biology department (457-2351). E-mail (kenc@monmouthcollege.edu) is also an excellent way to contact me.   2) Leave a message with the reason you cannot attend the exam. All absences from an exam due to sickness must be verified by a signed note from a doctor or the Dean of Students.  3) Schedule a makeup exam as soon as possible. Please reschedule within the next two days to take the exam no later than one week after the regularly scheduled exam. If you do not observe these 3 rules, you will not be allowed to take a makeup exam  Exam Rules During any examination, you should bring only writing utensils and yourself to the site of the exam. Leave all book bags, coats, hats, drinks, iPods, cell phones, etc. elsewhere. You may not leave the room once the exam has begun. Please use the restroom or take care of other needs before the exam. If you are too sick to stay seated and focused on an exam for 50 minutes, you are too sick to take the exam.
column2: How can I notify my instructor if I am unable to attend an exam due to an emergency or illness?
column3: Contact your instructor by calling their office, the biology department, or emailing them.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020. Lecture Exams and Final Exam (500 points) Lecture exams will consist of a variety of questions including fill-in-the-blank, matching, definition, short answer, and essay. You will be tested over all material presented in lecture and the reading assignments in the text. Material presented in labs that overlaps or duplicates material presented in lecture may also be on lecture exams. There may be information in the readings in your textbook, Campbell Biology, that we do not cover in lecture. If so, focus on the material we have covered in class. Also, I often will present additional material that is not in your textbook. You should pay special attention to this information as you will have no source other than the PowerPoint slides posted on-line and your own notes from lecture. The final exam will be twice as long as a regular exam; approximately one-half of the exam will cover material from the last few lectures of the semester that has not been covered on previous exams, and the other half of the exam will be comprehensive, that is, it will cover any material from the rest of the semester. Keep your old lecture exams and use them to study from for the final in addition to your notes. Under no circumstances will the time of the final exam be changed. You must attend the final at the time scheduled by Monmouth College. Incorporate the final time into other arrangements in your personal life (weddings, vacations, rides home, etc.).
column2: What types of questions will be on lecture exams?
column3: Fill-in-the-blank, matching, definition, short answer, and essay.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020. Lecture Reading Quizzes (approximately 50 points) Reading quizzes will be given periodically at the start of lecture. They will consist of five questions, typically fill in the blank or multiple choice, with maybe one very short written answer. The quiz will take no more than five minutes and will cover basic, fundamental concepts from the reading in your textbook, Campbell Biology.  Homework (approximately 150 points) You will hand in a variety of homework assignments from simple to complex. All of these will be assigned a point value (usually in the range of 5 to 20 points), graded and returned to you. Together with the reading quizzes they will count for 200 points out of the 1000 for the course, so you should complete them all. Late homework assignments are not accepted. Bring your completed homework to class on the due date assigned. Excuses about faulty printers, computers, or I forgot to print it off can I send it to you later are not acceptable. Get it done and bring it to class on the due date assigned. Please print on both sides of the paper, and if necessary, staple multiple sheets. Do not show up and ask me for a stapler. Do not e-mail me your homework.
column2: How many points in the course are associated with the homework and reading quizzes?
column3: 200 points

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020. Follow directions. If you do not follow directions in any assignment you submit, I will assign it zero points with no chance to resubmit. Reading and following directions is a minimal requirement at the college level, and in any job you might hope to obtain.  Laboratories, because of their design, cannot be "made up." Laboratory set-up is changed weekly and involves significant setup of materials in advance. Thus, rules for lab attendance are more rigid than for lecture. Please observe these rules: 1) Attend all labs unless there is a true emergency or you are very ill, or have an official school function (e.g. athletic contest not practice) that cannot be rescheduled. In any other case you must attend the lab day for which you are scheduled. If you are seriously ill, you can wait and come into lab on your own when you are feeling better, but you will miss my comments and help and will have to do all the learning independently. Missing a lab handicaps you in two ways: a) not only will you miss that weeks lab quiz and earn a zero but; b) you will handicap yourself for the next lab quiz.
column2: What are the consequences of missing a lab?
column3: Not only will you miss the lab quiz and receive a zero but you will also handicap yourself for the next lab quiz.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020. 4) You cannot be excused from a lab to attend athletic practice. Your coaches are aware of this and will not punish you for being late to practice in order to attend lab. Lab Preparation  You should read thoroughly the lab handout before you come to lab. There may be questions about the current lab (not just the previous labs) on the lab quiz. Lab Quizzes (250 points)  Lab quizzes are worth 25 points each and are given promptly at the beginning of lab each week; if you are late for lab, you will be pressed for time to finish the quiz. Quizzes are cumulative or comprehensive. While they will focus primarily on material presented in the previous laboratory session, they will include questions about the previous labs and general questions about the upcoming lab. You should set aside an hour or more to study for these quizzes; cramming material in the 5-10 minutes immediately before lab will not be sufficient. You will take 12 quizzes, dropping the two lowest. Lab Sketchbook (50 points) Turn in your lab sketchbook at this time as well. Your drawings will be graded based primarily on the following criteria: 1) all drawings are labeled appropriately, including important structures; 2) all specimens examined were sketched; 3) drawings were detailed enough to provide some learning of significant, distinguishing features.
column2: What is the point value of each lab quiz?
column3: 25 points

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020. Lecture Portfolio The lecture portfolio is simply your accumulation and organization of all the work you have submitted to me for a grade in the lecture portion of this course. This means all four regular exams, all homework and quizzes, and any extra credit that may have been offered and completed. Your work should be organized in a 3-ring binder as follows: exams first; reading quizzes next; homework next; extra credit last. Within each of these groups, organize them in order of the date it was submitted (earliest to latest). Complete portfolios following these guidelines will receive 20 bonus points added to your point total for the semester. Anything less than a complete portfolio will receive no credit; no partial credit is given for portfolios. Lecture portfolios are due on the date of the final. Late portfolios are not accepted. Lab Portfolio  The lab portfolio is all your materials from lab organized in a 3-ring binder. It should include the following in this order: 1) your lab manual (by week) with any lab notes associated with that weeks lab; 2) lab quizzes; 3) lab practical exams; 4) and finally, lab reports. Within each of these groups, arrange them in chronological order. Complete portfolios following these guidelines will receive full credit of 20 bonus points added to your point total for the semester. Anything less than a complete portfolio will receive no credit; partial credit is not given for portfolios. Lab portfolios are due the last Monday of regularly scheduled classes and will be returned at the final exam. Late portfolios are not accepted.
column2: What kind of organization is required in a lecture portfolio?
column3: The lecture portfolio should be organized in a 3-ring binder with exams first, followed by reading quizzes, homework, and extra credit, in chronological order.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020. Lecture Portfolio The lecture portfolio is simply your accumulation and organization of all the work you have submitted to me for a grade in the lecture portion of this course. This means all four regular exams, all homework and quizzes, and any extra credit that may have been offered and completed. Your work should be organized in a 3-ring binder as follows: exams first; reading quizzes next; homework next; extra credit last. Within each of these groups, organize them in order of the date it was submitted (earliest to latest). Complete portfolios following these guidelines will receive 20 bonus points added to your point total for the semester. Anything less than a complete portfolio will receive no credit; no partial credit is given for portfolios. Lecture portfolios are due on the date of the final. Late portfolios are not accepted. Lab Portfolio  The lab portfolio is all your materials from lab organized in a 3-ring binder. It should include the following in this order: 1) your lab manual (by week) with any lab notes associated with that weeks lab; 2) lab quizzes; 3) lab practical exams; 4) and finally, lab reports. Within each of these groups, arrange them in chronological order. Complete portfolios following these guidelines will receive full credit of 20 bonus points added to your point total for the semester. Anything less than a complete portfolio will receive no credit; partial credit is not given for portfolios. Lab portfolios are due the last Monday of regularly scheduled classes and will be returned at the final exam. Late portfolios are not accepted.
column2: Are lecture portfolios eligible for partial credit?
column3: No, lecture portfolios are not eligible for partial credit; anything less than a complete portfolio will receive no credit.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020. Policies on Academic Dishonesty From the Monmouth College Academic Honesty Policy: We view academic dishonesty as a threat to the integrity and intellectual mission of our institution.Any breach of the academic honesty policy either intentionally or unintentionally - will be taken seriously and may result not only in failure in the course, but in suspension or expulsion from the college. It is each students responsibility to read, understand and comply with the general academic honesty policy at Monmouth College, as defined here in the Scots Guide, and to the specific guidelines for each course, as elaborated on the professors syllabus.  The following areas are examples of violations of the academic honesty policy:  Cheating on tests, labs, etc;  Plagiarism, i.e., using the words, ideas, writing, or work of another without giving appropriate credit; Improper collaboration between students, i.e., not doing ones own work on outside assignments specified as group projects by the instructor;
column2: What is considered an example of an academic dishonesty violation?
column3: Cheating on tests, labs, Plagiarism, Improper collaboration between students, Looking at anothers test, Providing false information in connection with an academic exercise, Submitting work to satisfy the requirements of two or more courses without permission, Duplicating materials without permission.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Cramer in 2020. Submitting work previously submitted in another course, without previous authorization by the instructor. Please note that this list is not intended to be exhaustive. The complete Monmouth College Academic Honesty Policy can be found on the College web page by clicking on Student Life then on Scots Guide in the navigation bar to the left, then Academic Regulations in the navigation bar at the left. Or you can visit the web page directly at this URL: http://department.monm.edu/stuserv/student-handbook/academic.htm In this course, any violation of the academic honesty policy will have varying consequences depending on the severity of the infraction. Minimally, a violation will result in an F or 0 points on the assignment in question. Additionally, the students course grade may be lowered by one letter grade. In severe cases, the student will be assigned a course grade of F and dismissed from the class. All cases of academic dishonesty will be reported to the Associate Dean who may decide to recommend further action to the Admissions and Academic Status Committee, including suspension or dismissal. It is assumed that students will educate themselves regarding what is considered to be academic dishonesty, so no excuses will be accepted to mitigate the consequences of such violations.
column2: What are the minimum consequences for academic dishonesty?
column3: An F or 0 points on the assignment, and the student's course grade may be lowered by one letter grade.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Engstrom in 2023. This course introduces the biology major (non-majors welcome!) to the diversity of life by examining it in an evolutionary and ecological context. It is designed as a natural progression from Biology 150, though Biology 155 may be taken independently. Beginning with an  introduction to the mechanisms of evolution, we will investigate the evolutionary history of biological diversity, the structure and function of organisms, and the ecological contexts in which organisms interact and evolution occurs. In lab, we will investigate the broad range of biological diversity including: bacteria, protists, fungi, plants and animals. Alternatively, those of you enrolled in the SEA-PHAGES lab will investigate how we make sense of biodiversity at the genetic level, an area known as bioinformatics.  Welcome to Introduction to Ecology, Evolution and Diversity! Time: Lecture: MWF, 11:00-11:50 AM  Laboratory: T, 10:00-11:50 AM &   Th, 8:00-9:50 AM (Section 1)   Th, 1:00-3:50 PM (Section 2)  Place: Lecture:Wallace Hall 113
column2: What is the structure of this course?
column3: This course includes an introduction to the mechanisms of evolution, investigations into the evolutionary history of biological diversity, the structure and function of organisms, and the ecological contexts in which organisms interact and evolution occurs. Lab sections include investigations into a broad range of biological diversity including bacteria, protists, fungi, plants, and animals.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Laboratory: CSB 172 (Section 1)   CSB 170 (Section 2)  Instructor: Eric Engstrom   Office: CSB 242  Phone: 309-457-2445  E-mail: eengstrom@monmouthcollege.edu Office Hours: M,W 2-5 PM  Prerequisites: None.  1 Required Texts  1) Urry L.A., Cain M.L., Wasserman S.A., Minorsky P.V., Reece, J. B. (2017) Campbell Biology 11th Edition. Pearson. ISBN 9780134093413. Required for all sections.  2) Adams B.J. and Crawley J. L. 2018. Van De Graaaffs Photographic Atlas for the Biology Laboratory. 8th Edition. Morton Publishing, 280 pp. ISBN-9781617317651. Required for Section 1 only.  3) Strathmore (or other) drawing paper sketch book, at least 24 sheets, and pencils, plain or colored. Required for Section 1 only.  Please note that required texts are required. Section 1 students, points will be deducted from your lab grade if you do not have your Photographic Atlas for all labs beginning in the second week.  Disclaimer: This syllabus is intended to give the student guidance in what may be covered and how students are likely to be assessed during the semester and will be followed as closely as possible. However, the professor reserves the right to modify, supplement and make changes in response to course needs as they arise.
column2: What texts are required for Section 1 students?
column3: Campbell Biology 11th Edition by Urry L.A., Cain M.L., Wasserman S.A., Minorsky P.V., Reece, J. B. and Van De Graaaffs Photographic Atlas for the Biology Laboratory 8th Edition by Adams B.J. and Crawley J. L.

B. (2017) Campbell Biology 11th Edition. Pearson. ISBN 9780134093413. Required for all sections.  2) Adams B.J. and Crawley J. L. 2018. Van De Graaaffs Photographic Atlas for the Biology Laboratory. 8th Edition. Morton Publishing, 280 pp. ISBN-9781617317651. Required for Section 1 only.  3) Strathmore (or other) drawing paper sketch book, at least 24 sheets, and pencils, plain or colored. Required for Section 1 only.  Please note that required texts are required. Section 1 students, points will be deducted from your lab grade if you do not have your Photographic Atlas for all labs beginning in the second week.  Disclaimer: This syllabus is intended to give the student guidance in what may be covered and how students are likely to be assessed during the semester and will be followed as closely as possible. However, the professor reserves the right to modify, supplement and make changes in response to course needs as they arise.
column2: What material is required for Section 1 students?
column3: Campbell Biology 11th Edition, Van De Graaaffs Photographic Atlas for the Biology Laboratory 8th Edition, and a Strathmore (or other) Drawing Paper Sketchbook with at least 24 sheets and pencils, plain or colored.
