column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Students will be able to articulate and explain the mechanisms by which biological evolution occurs.  Students will be able to explain how evolution by natural selection explains the origin of biological diversity and the basis for biological unity, with reference to documented examples.  Students will be able to explain the biological species concept and articulate several mechanisms for maintaining species boundaries.  Students will be able to explain the concept of population and explain why a population is the unit of biological evolution.  Students will be able to explain how the Hardy-Weinberg equation reflects the frequency of alleles within a gene pool and employ the Hardy-Weinberg equation to determine if a population is evolving with respect to a particular gene.  Students will be able to describe the sequence of several major events in the history of life on Earth. Students will be able to explain the significance of adaptive radiation and major extinction events in the history of life on Earth.
column2: What is the biological species concept?
column3: The biological species concept defines a species as a group of organisms capable of interbreeding and producing fertile offspring.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Students will be able to articulate and explain the mechanisms by which biological evolution occurs.  Students will be able to explain how evolution by natural selection explains the origin of biological diversity and the basis for biological unity, with reference to documented examples.  Students will be able to explain the biological species concept and articulate several mechanisms for maintaining species boundaries.  Students will be able to explain the concept of population and explain why a population is the unit of biological evolution.  Students will be able to explain how the Hardy-Weinberg equation reflects the frequency of alleles within a gene pool and employ the Hardy-Weinberg equation to determine if a population is evolving with respect to a particular gene.  Students will be able to describe the sequence of several major events in the history of life on Earth. Students will be able to explain the significance of adaptive radiation and major extinction events in the history of life on Earth.
column2: What is population?
column3: A population is a group of individuals of the same species living in the same area.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Students will be able to describe the sequence of several major events in the history of life on Earth. Students will be able to explain the significance of adaptive radiation and major extinction events in the history of life on Earth.
column2: What is the Hardy-Weinberg equation?
column3: The Hardy-Weinberg equation is a mathematical equation that describes how allele frequencies in a population remain constant from one generation to the next.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Students will be able to describe the endosymbiotic theory of mitochondrion and/or plastid evolution, and to describe evidence supporting the endosymbiotic model.  Students will be able to correctly interpret a phylogenetic tree  Students will be able to describe how phylogenetic trees are constructed.  Systems  Students will be able to define ecosystem.  Students will be able to define climate and to explain how climate emerges from the shape of the Earth, the tilt of the Earths axis of rotation relative to the plane of Earths orbit, and the distribution of land and oceans.  Students will be able to explain how climate contributes to determining the location and characteristics of terrestrial biomes.  Students will be able to describe factors that limit the range of species within a biome.  Students will be able to describe how light availability contributes to structuring ocean ecosystems.  Students will be able to describe factors determining how organisms may be distributed within an ecosystem.
column2: What is the endosymbiotic theory?
column3: The endosymbiotic theory proposes that mitochondria and plastids originated from the engulfment of a smaller cell by a larger cell.

Students will be able to describe factors determining how organisms may be distributed within an ecosystem.
column2: How is a phylogenetic tree created?
column3: A phylogenetic tree is constructed by comparing the genetic sequences of species to determine their relationship and evolutionary history.

column2: What are the factors that limit the range of species within a biome?
column3: Factors that limit the range of species within a biome include temperature, precipitation, competition and predation.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Engstrom in 2023. 3 Students will be able to explain how the logistic growth equation describes population size dynamics.  Students will be able to describe the demographic transition and explain its relevance to our understanding of human population dynamics.  Students will be able to describe competition, exploitation and mutualism, with reference to specific examples.  Students will be able to describe the relationship between selection, competition, niche partitioning and character displacement.  Students will be able to define species diversity, species richness and relative species abundance.  Students will be able to explain why trophic webs consist of a limited number of trophic levels.  Students will be able to explain the process of ecological succession with reference to one or more specific documented examples.  Students will be able to describe the ecological meaning of disturbance.  Students will be able to explain why energy must flow through an ecosystem, while matter has the potential to cycle within an ecosystem.
column2: What is logistic growth equation?
column3: The logistic growth equation is an S-shaped curve used to describe the population dynamics of species.

Students will be able to describe the ecological meaning of disturbance.  Students will be able to explain why energy must flow through an ecosystem, while matter has the potential to cycle within an ecosystem.
column2: What is the demographic transition?
column3: The demographic transition is a model that describes the shift from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates as a country develops and its standard of living increases.

column2: What is niche partitioning?
column3: Niche partitioning is the process by which species sharing the same habitat adapt to occupy different niches and use different resources.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Students will be able to describe the ecological meaning of limiting.  Structure and Function  Students will be able to formulate arguments both for and against the contention that viruses are alive. Students will be able to describe the fundamental structure of viruses.  Pathways and Transformations of Energy and Matter  Students will be able to describe the lifecycle of a typical animal virus and of a typical bacteriophage.  Ability to Apply the Process of Science  Students will be able to explain what distinguishes the process of scientific inquiry from other forms of inquiry, and to accurately define the terms model, theory,  experiment andhypothesis. Ability to Use Quantitative Reasoning  Students will be able to explain the rationale underlying biological sampling, and to describe the mark-recapture method. 4 Assessment: Student mastery of the course material will be assessed on the basis of: All Sections  Midterm Exams30% of final grade. We will have three midterm exams during the semester.
column2: What is the ecological meaning of limiting?
column3: Limiting refers to an environmental or ecological condition where an ecosystem is unable to produce enough of a given resource to sustain itself.

column2: What are the four means of assessing student mastery of the course material?
column3: The means of assessing student mastery of the course material are midterm exams (30% of final grade), quizzes, written assignments, and lab practicals.

column2: What is the mark-recapture method?
column3: The mark-recapture method is a technique used in ecology and population biology to estimate the size of a population using a random sample of marked individuals.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Engstrom in 2023. 2) Lab exams are given weekly and there are no make-up quizzes. You will simply drop that quiz as the lowest one for the semester. Quizzes will be given at the start of class. Be punctual, or you will be pressed for time to finish.  3) You cannot be excused from a lab to attend athletic practice. Your coaches are aware of this and will not punish you for being late to practice in order to attend lab.  4) The course policy on informational devices applies to lab as well as lecture, with one exception: you may use cameras to document your lab findings.  Lab Preparation  You should read thoroughly the lab handout before you come to lab. There may be questions about the current lab (not just the previous labs) on the lab quiz.  Lab Quizzes  Lab quizzes are worth 25 points each and are given promptly at the beginning of lab each week; if you are late for lab, you will be pressed for time to finish the quiz. Quizzes are cumulative or comprehensive. While they will focus primarily on material presented in the previous laboratory session, they will include questions about the previous labs and general questions about the upcoming lab. You should set aside an hour or more to study for these quizzes; cramming material in the 5-10 minutes immediately before lab will not be sufficient.
column2: How should I prepare for lab quizzes?
column3: Read the lab handout thoroughly and allocate at least an hour to studying for the quiz.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Lab Sketchbook Your drawings will be graded based primarily on the following criteria: 1) all drawings are labeled appropriately, including important structures; 2) all specimens examined were sketched; 3) drawings were detailed enough to provide some learning of significant, distinguishing features. 6 Section 1 Laboratory: Most of you in Section 1 are continuing the SEA-PHAGES lab experience that you began last semester. Last semesters lab emphasized isolating novel phage from environmental samples, phage amplification, and phage characterization. This semester will begin with annotating the genomes of the two phages isolated at Monmouth last semester, and will culminate in a research project to be determined.  Course Engagement Expectations: This course is scheduled to meet 3 days per week for lecture, for 50 minute periods, as well as one day or two days per week for lab, a 170 minute period and 220 minute periods respectively. That brings us to 320/370 minutes of classroom instruction per week. How much additional time you will require outside of the classroom for reading and working problem sets will vary among individuals and among topics, but on average a student should expect to spend a minimum of 14 hours per week on this course.
column2: Question1: How will our drawings be graded?
column3: Drawings will be graded primarily based on labeling, sketching all specimens examined, and providing an accurate learning of any significant, distinguishing features.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Attendance: If you are absent for a class, you might get an e-mail from me just to check up and make certain all is well. Consistently coming to class late, or not at all, will negatively impact your class participation grade. However, if you want to make up a missed quiz, exam, or lecture activity, you will need a note from some verifiable higher power stating that you were dead or nearly so, or some very extreme circumstances prevailed to prevent your attendance. If you know in advance that you cannot make a specific date, let me know in advance and we can plan ahead.  Staples and Attribution: You will not receive credit for any work submitted without your name written legibly somewhere in the vicinity of the top, right-hand corner. You will not receive credit for work consisting of multiple pieces of paper, unless the papers are stapled securely together.  Information Devices: Notebook computers have become a serious distraction for many students (and instructors). I ask that you refrain from having a notebook computer open during class. Exceptions will be made for students with a legitimate need for use of a notebook computer during class. Please ensure that phones are turned off and placed out of site before class begins. Repeated failure to cooperate with the phone policy will negatively impact your class participation grade. It will be helpful at times to have a calculator in lecture and you are permitted to use a calculator on exams. Please remove earbuds from ears during all class periods.
column2: What happens if I am consistently late to class or absent?
column3: Your class participation grade will be negatively impacted.

Information Devices: Notebook computers have become a serious distraction for many students (and instructors). I ask that you refrain from having a notebook computer open during class. Exceptions will be made for students with a legitimate need for use of a notebook computer during class. Please ensure that phones are turned off and placed out of site before class begins. Repeated failure to cooperate with the phone policy will negatively impact your class participation grade. It will be helpful at times to have a calculator in lecture and you are permitted to use a calculator on exams. Please remove earbuds from ears during all class periods.
column2: Are notebook computers allowed during class?
column3: Notebook computers are generally not allowed, but exceptions can be made upon request for students with a legitimate need for use.

column1: This class is BIO 155, Intro to ecology evolution and diversity, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Supplemental Instruction (SI): Supplemental Instruction (SI) will be provided for all students who want to improve their understanding of the material taught in this course. SI sessions are led by a fellow student who has already mastered the course material and has been trained to facilitate group sessions where you can meet to compare class notes, review and discuss important concepts, develop appropriate strategies for studying, and prepare for exams. Attendance is FREE and voluntary. You may attend as many times as you want.  Check it out at least once those participating in SI have been demonstrated to do better in this course! Session days and times will be posted in the classroom and online at http://www.monmouthcollege.edu/ academics/support/tlc/supplemental-instruction.aspx SI leaders also have posted office hours and you are welcome to visit them during that time for additional assistance with class questions and material.  7 Student Success at Monmouth College: Student Success & Accessibility Services offers FREE resources to assist Monmouth College students with their academic success. Programs include Supplemental Instruction for difficult classes as well as Drop-In and appointment tutoring. Our office is here to help all students excel academically, since every can work toward better grades, practice stronger study skills, and manage their time better.
column2: What is Supplemental Instruction?
column3: Supplemental Instruction (SI) is a facilitated group sessions that includes comparing class notes, reviewing and discussing key concepts, and learning appropriate strategies for studying and preparing for exams.

column1: This class is BIO 201, Field Botany, taught by Engstrom in 2022. Office Hours: M 2-3:30 pm; W,Th 2 p.m. to 5 p.m.  Prerequisites: None. Required Textbook: Newcombs Wildflower Guide by Lawrence Newcomb. (2011. Little, Brown and Company. ISBN 9780316604420).  Forest Trees of Illinois by University of Illinois Extension. (2009. ISBN 9781883097646).  Optional Textbook: Plant Identification Terminology: An Illustrated Glossary, 2nd edition by James Harris and Melinda Harris. (2001. Spring Lake Publishing. ISBN-13 978-0964022164).  1 Reference Texts: Illustrated Companion to Gleason and Cronquist's Manual: illustrations of the vascular plants of northeastern United States and adjacent Canada by Noel H. Holmgren; with the artistic and editorial assistance of Patricia K. Holmgren. 1998  Guide to the vascular flora of Illinois by Mohlenbrock, Robert H. 1986.  Michigan ferns and lycophytes: a guide to species of the Great Lakes region by Palmer, Daniel D. 2018. Reference Websites:Illinois Wildflowers by John Hilty. https://illinoiswildflowers.info/index.htm. Illinois Native Plant Society. https://illinoisplants.org/
column2: What is the required textbook for this class?
column3: Newcombs Wildflower Guide by Lawrence Newcomb.

column1: This class is BIO 201, Field Botany, taught by Engstrom in 2022. PLANTS Database. https://plants.sc.egov.usda.gov/home  Flora of North America. http://floranorthamerica.org/Main_Page  Royal Botanic Gardens Kew. https://www.kew.org/  World Flora Online. http://www.worldfloraonline.org/  Plant Collection. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2wFN9YmkBOQ  Mounting a Specimen. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HaaX5WzlAil (maybe)  Disclaimer: This syllabus is intended to give the student guidance in what may be covered during the semester and will be followed as closely as possible. However, the professor reserves the right to modify, supplement and make changes in response to course needs as they arise.  General Instructional Objectives  We will understand the components of plant anatomy and morphology and apply them in plant identification.  We will understand how plant associations are formed and maintained in the landscape.  We will visit different field sites and experience their floras  We will produce an archival quality, identified, mounted and annotated plant collection.
column2: How do I use the PLANTS database?
column3: Go to https://plants.sc.egov.usda.gov/home, and enter information in the search bar to find related information.

column2: What is the objective of the course?

Moreover, students will visit different field sites, experience their floras, and produce an archival quality, identified, mounted and annotated plant collection.

column1: This class is BIO 201, Field Botany, taught by Engstrom in 2022. We will learn to think and communicate clearly and precisely about plants. 2 Assessment: Student mastery of the course goals will be assessed on the basis of:  Midterm Exam15% of final grade. Exams will cover material from lecture period as well as field and laboratory experiences. Exams will have the format of short-answer, fill in the blank, and multiple choice. Midterm exam is scheduled for Thursday October 6th.  Comprehensive Final Exam25% of final grade. Format will be the same as the Midterm Exam. Final exam is scheduled for Friday, December 10th at 6:30 pm.  Quizzes25% of final grade. Quizzes will test material and skills encountered in the field and laboratory. You will be expected to recognize and give both the Latin name and common name of species seen in earlier field trips/lab exercises, as well as the terminology required to identify these species. You will be exposed to both living material and preserved herbarium specimens. A running list of species you are responsible for will be maintained and posted on Moodle. You will be expected to identify unknown species using your keys. Partial credit will be awarded whenever possible. Quizzes need not be announced in advance.
column2: What type of questions can be found on midterm and final exams?
column3: Short-answer, fill-in-the-blank, and multiple choice.

column2: What will quizzes test?
column3: Material and skills encountered in the field and laboratory, recognizing and giving the Latin name and common name of species, identifying unknown species using keys.

column1: This class is BIO 201, Field Botany, taught by Engstrom in 2022. Plant Collection25% of final grade. Note that the plant collection is a major portion of your final grade. You will not have regular homework assignments, lengthy reading assignments, etc.  throughout the semester. However, you should work on your plant collection throughout the semester. If you wait until the end, the quality of your collection will likely suffer, and so will your grade. I will be available during office hours and by appointment to help you with identifications, mounting, etc. See Plant Collection Guidelines for details. Do not procrastinate. Plant Collections are due Wednesday, Dec. 7th at 5:00 P.M. Presentation10% of final grade. You will give a 15-20 minute presentation to the class on a specific plant family of your choice. You should discuss the anatomy, taxonomy, distribution, historical importance, and current economic importance of the plant family you choose. You will turn in your presentation, along with a bibliography. I have numerous resources of my own that you may peruse to get started. This is not meant to be a stressful or intimidating event. This class is small enough, and by the end of the semester you should be quite comfortable with your classmates, so think of it as your chance to share some info that youve discovered about a plant family! Family choices will be made by midterm and presentations will be made during the final lab periods of class. I will give an example presentation so you have an idea of what I am looking for.
column2: When is the plant collection due?
column3: Wednesday, Dec. 7th at 5:00 PM.

Family choices will be made by midterm and presentations will be made during the final lab periods of class. I will give an example presentation so you have an idea of what I am looking for.
column2: What are the topics I should cover in the presentation?
column3: Anatomy, Taxonomy, Distribution, Historical Importance, Current Economic Importance.

column1: This class is BIO 201, Field Botany, taught by Engstrom in 2022. Plant Collection25% of final grade. Note that the plant collection is a major portion of your final grade. You will not have regular homework assignments, lengthy reading assignments, etc.  throughout the semester. However, you should work on your plant collection throughout the semester. If you wait until the end, the quality of your collection will likely suffer, and so will your grade. I will be available during office hours and by appointment to help you with identifications, mounting, etc. See Plant Collection Guidelines for details. Do not procrastinate. Plant Collections are due Wednesday, Dec. 7th at 5:00 P.M. Presentation10% of final grade. You will give a 15-20 minute presentation to the class on a specific plant family of your choice. You should discuss the anatomy, taxonomy, distribution, historical importance, and current economic importance of the plant family you choose. You will turn in your presentation, along with a bibliography. I have numerous resources of my own that you may peruse to get started. This is not meant to be a stressful or intimidating event. This class is small enough, and by the end of the semester you should be quite comfortable with your classmates, so think of it as your chance to share some info that youve discovered about a plant family! Family choices will be made by midterm and presentations will be made during the final lab periods of class. I will give an example presentation so you have an idea of what I am looking for.
column2: How should I approach the presentation?
column3: Relaxed, Comfortable, Share Info.

column1: This class is BIO 201, Field Botany, taught by Engstrom in 2022. Field Trips: Be prepared! We plan to spend as much time in the field as possible, so short of a blizzard or tornado threat, we will try to go out. That means you need to come prepared with appropriate clothing: rain gear, layers, hats/sunglasses. Bugs should be less of an issue, but bring some insect repellent if they bug you. A hat will keep them out of your hair. We may wind up going through some wet areas; dry socks and shoes may make you more comfortable on your ride back to campus. Waterproof, GORTEX boots may be an advantage. Sandals are a bad idea; really a terrible idea. Even on a beautiful day, I recommend wearing long pants and bringing along a long-sleeved shirt. We will be walking through nasty things like poison ivy, stinging nettles, buckthorn, etc. (these are the plants of Illinois!). A layer of clothing between you and them will keep you more comfortable, and may save on itches later. Bring water to stave off dehydration. Bring a snack if you are likely to get the munchies in the early afternoon - we are not likely to run into too many vending machines. Finally, a major objective of this class is for you to learn to identify the plants of Illinois on your own. To do this you will need your ID books. Bring your books and a notebook on every field trip, and to every lab.
column2: What kind of clothing should I bring on field trips?
column3: Appropriate clothing like rain gear, layers, hats/sunglasses, and possibly waterproof GORTEX boots and long pants.

column2: What should I bring on field trips to help in identifying plants?
column3: A notebook and one of the ID books.

column1: This class is BIO 201, Field Botany, taught by Engstrom in 2022. Photography and Drawing: One excellent way to develop ones skills at observing (and thinking about!) plants, is to photograph them. So we will take some time in the field to hone our skills at photography. How much emphasis we place on photography as we move through the course will depend upon several factors, including your level of interest in photography as a class, and the number of suitable cameras available for our use. If you have a digital SLR camera, you are strongly encouraged to bring it with you into the field (with appropriate precautions taken to protect your equipment from the elements). If you have been thinking about getting a digital SLR for some time, but just havent gotten around to it, now might the time: you will have lots of opportunity to learn to use it well.  Come talk with me if you are interested in exploring botanical drawing.  Attendance: You can skip whatever classes or labs you want. Youre adults, and I dont take it personally. You might get an e-mail from me just to check up and make certain all is well. If you are absent, you remain responsible for any material/deadlines assigned that day, and I will not provide assignments under these circumstances by e-mail unless you are unable to come to my office.
column2: Can I bring my digital SLR camera to take field photos?
column3: Yes, you are strongly encouraged to bring it with you.

column1: This class is BIO 201, Field Botany, taught by Engstrom in 2022. Staples and Attribution: You will not receive credit for any work submitted without your name written legibly somewhere in the vicinity of the top, right-hand corner. You will not receive credit for work consisting of multiple pieces of paper, unless the papers are stapled securely together.  4 Information Devices: Notebook computers have become a serious distraction for many students (and instructors) in lecture format courses. I ask that you refrain from having a notebook computer open during class. Exceptions will be made for students with a legitimate need for use of a notebook computer during class. Please ensure that phones are turned off and placed out of site in lecture and laboratory. Likewise smartwatches. No earbuds in ears during class please.  Academic Honesty: From the Monmouth College Academic Honesty Policy: We view academic dishonesty as a threat to the integrity and intellectual mission of our institution. Any breach of the academic honesty policy either intentionally or unintentionally - will be taken seriously and may result not only in failure in the course, but in suspension or expulsion from the college. It is each students responsibility to read, understand and comply with the general academic honesty policy at Monmouth College, as defined here in the Scots Guide, and to the specific guidelines for each course, as elaborated on the professors syllabus.
column2: What should be written on the top right-hand corner of a submitted work?
column3: Students' name.

column1: This class is BIO 212, Plant Biology, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Although fungi are heterotrophic and are more closely related to animals than to plants, we will consider fungi as well, partly in deference to historical treatments of fungi under the general heading of Botany, partly to provide us with another life-strategy to compare with that of terrestrial plants, partly because fungi would not otherwise receive the coverage they warrant in the curriculum, and primarily because most of what we think of as plants are in fact  embryophyte/fungal symbioses.  This course employs lecture and primary-literature discussion components to provide you with a comprehensive introduction to major topics in fundamental plant biology. Our treatment of photosynthetic organisms and fungi will integrate spatial scales moving from biochemistry, molecular biology and genetics, through cell biology, physiology and development, and ecology. We will also consider systematics and the evolution of land plants.  Welcome to Plant Biology! Time: Lecture: MWF, 1:00-1:50 PM  Laboratory: Th, 11:00-12:30 PM
column2: What type of organisms are considered in this course of Plant Biology?
column3: Fungi, photosynthetic organisms and land plants.

column3: Biochemistry, molecular biology, genetics, cell biology, physiology, development, ecology and systematics.

column1: This class is BIO 212, Plant Biology, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Place: Lecture:Wallace Hall Room 102  Laboratory: Wallace Hall Room 102  Instructor: Eric Engstrom   Office: CSB 242  Phone: 309-457-2445  E-mail: eengstrom@monmouthcollege.edu Office Hours: T 10 AM to 1 PM and Th 1 to 4 PM  1 Prerequisites: BIO 150 and BIO 155.  Required Textbook: Biology of Plants. 8th Edition by Raven, Evert and Eichhorn. (2013. W.H. Freeman and Company. ISBN 978-1-4292-1961-7).  Disclaimer: This syllabus is intended to give the student guidance in what may be covered during the semester and will be followed as closely as possible. However, the professor reserves the right to modify, supplement and make changes in response to course needs as they arise.  General Instructional Objectives  Students will significantly deepen their understanding of photosynthesis.  Students will develop an appreciation for the evolution and diversity of terrestrial plants.  Students will be able to describe many of cellular, developmental, and life-history traits that distinguish terrestrial plants from other multicellular taxa.
column2: What is the instructor's name?
column3: Eric Engstrom

column1: This class is BIO 212, Plant Biology, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Class Participation10% of final grade. Active engagement and asking questions during lecture/discussions are strongly encouraged.  Quizzes15% of final grade. Quizzes will be given in class, will consist of multiple-choice or short-answer questions, will take no more than 10 minutes to complete each, and may be, but need not be, announced in advance.  Literature Searching5% of final grade. Students will weekly nominate primary literature papers for future discussion.  Paper Presentations20% of final grade. Each student will lead two Thursday paper discussions.  If at any point during the course, you would like to know the status of your grade, you are welcome to come by my office and I will let you know what your up-to-the-minute grade is. I will not give you your grade by e-mail. Course Engagement Expectations: This course is scheduled to meet 3 days per week for lecture, for 50 minute periods, as well as one day per week for literature discussion, a 90 minute period. That brings us to 240 minutes of classroom instruction per week. How much additional time you will require outside of the classroom for reading and working problem sets will vary among individuals and among topics, but on average a student should expect to spend a minimum of 14 hours per week on this course.
column2: How much of the final grade is made up of quizzes?

column1: This class is BIO 212, Plant Biology, taught by Engstrom in 2023. Attendance: You can skip whatever classes or labs you want. Youre adults, and I dont take it personally. You might get an e-mail from me just to check up and make certain all is well. If you are absent, you remain responsible for any material/deadlines assigned that day, and I will not provide assignments under these circumstances by e-mail unless you are unable to come to my office.  Staples and Attribution: You will not receive credit for any work submitted without your name written legibly somewhere in the vicinity of the top, right-hand corner. You will not receive credit for work consisting of multiple pieces of paper, unless the papers are stapled securely together.  Information Devices: Notebook computers have become a serious distraction for many students (and instructors) in lecture format courses. I ask that you refrain from having a notebook computer open during class. Exceptions will be made for students with a legitimate need for use of a notebook computer during class. Please ensure that phones are turned off and placed out of site in lecture and laboratory.
column2: Does skipping class make me exempt from associated deadlines and assignments?
column3: No, you remain responsible for any material/deadlines assigned that day.

column1: This class is BIO 212, Plant Biology, taught by Engstrom in 2023. 4 Teaching & Learning Center: The Teaching and Learning Center offers FREE resources to assist Monmouth College students with their academic success. Programs include Supplemental Instruction for difficult classes, Drop-In and appointment tutoring, and individual Academic Coaching as well as College Knowledge Series workshops. The TLC is here to help students excel academically. TLC services are not just for struggling students, but can assist all students to get better grades, practice stronger study skills, and manage time.  Make an appointment with Kam Williams, Director of Academic Support Programs and Student Disability Services, at the TLC on the 2nd floor of Poling Hall. The Department phone number is 457-2257, or contact the department online at http://ou.monmouthcollege.edu/academics/teaching-learning-center/  We can also be reached via email at: tlc@monmouthcollege.edu Like the TLC on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Monmouth-College-Teaching- and-Learning-Center/203117166403210?ref=aymt_homepage_panel

column1: This class is BIO 212, Plant Biology, taught by Engstrom in 2023. The following areas are examples of violations of the academic honesty policy:  1. Cheating on tests, labs, etc;  2. Plagiarism, i.e., using the words, ideas, writing, or work of another without giving  appropriate credit;  3. Improper collaboration between students, i.e., not doing ones own work on outside  assignments specified as group projects by the instructor;  4. Submitting work previously submitted in another course, without previous authorization  by the instructor.  Please note that this list is not intended to be exhaustive.  The complete Monmouth College Academic Honesty Policy can be found on the College web page by clicking on Student Life then on Scots Guide in the navigation bar to the left, then Academic Regulations in the navigation bar at the left. Or you can visit the web page directly by typing in this URL: http://department.monm.edu/stuserv/student-handbook/academic.htm In this course, any violation of the academic honesty policy will have varying consequences depending on the severity of the infraction as judged by the instructor. Minimally, a violation will result in an F or 0 points on the assignment in question. Additionally, the students course grade may be lowered by one letter grade. In severe cases, the student will be assigned a course grade of F and dismissed from the class. All cases of academic dishonesty will be reported to the Associate Dean who may decide to recommend further action to the Admissions and Academic Status Committee, including suspension or dismissal. It is assumed that students will educate themselves regarding what is considered to be academic dishonesty, so excuses or claims of ignorance will not mitigate the consequences of any violations.
column2: What are examples of academic dishonesty?
column3: Cheating on tests, labs, etc., plagiarism, improper collaboration between students, and submitting work previously submitted in another course without authorization by the instructor.

column1: This class is CHEM 140, General Chemistry, taught by Sturgeon in 2023. Other required materials: Aktiv Account (online homework) Notebook for homework journal Duplicating notebook for the laboratory Laboratory safety glasses Scientific Calculator (cell phones are not allowed on exams)  GRADING: Grades will be assigned on the following percentages from the points accumulated. We reserve the right to relax the percentages (i.e, an 89 may be an A- rather than a B+) but not tighten them. Grading Weight Grade % Homework and Quizzes 10% A >92 Class/Group Participation/Attendance 5% A- 90-92 Midterm Exams 40% B+ 88-90 Final Exam 20% B 83-88 Laboratory  25% B- 80-82 C+ 78-80 C 72-78 C- 70-72 D 60-69 F <60 HOURS PER WEEK WORK EXPECTATION: There is an expectation that you will complete significant work outside of the classroom and laboratory. Understand that the hours listed in the table are weekly averages. Some weeks may demand more than others; for example, in weeks that you have an exam you will need to spend more time. Additionally, some students may need more time to master the material. For example, if you have not retained the knowledge from your high school math and science courses, you may need to spend more time studying the material for general chemistry.
column2: What materials are required for the course?
column3: Aktiv Account (online homework), Notebook for homework journal, Duplicating notebook for laboratory, Laboratory safety glasses, Scientific Calculator (cell phones not allowed on exams).

column1: This class is CHEM 140, General Chemistry, taught by Sturgeon in 2023. More than 4 unexcused absences will result in course grade of F. For an excused absence, please notify me before class if possible. If you are more than 5 minutes late, it will be recorded as an absence. READING ASSIGNMENTS: Reading assignments will be provided during class. You should skim each chapter before it is discussed in class. Pay careful attention to the figures, diagrams, and example problems in each chapter; if you understand these, you are 90% of the way to understanding the material. HOMEWORK: Any discipline requires practice. Most homework will be assigned and evaluated using a web-based program called Aktiv (Aktiv.com). You will be required to purchase access online using a credit card. Please see me if you have financial aid that requires purchase through the bookstore. Online homework assignments will be announced in lecture and will be clearly displayed upon logging into your Aktiv account. Email will be used to announce/remind students of new assignments if not announced in lecture/lab. Aktiv gives you instant feedback on the homework assignments. If an incorrect response is entered, you will be given multiple attempts to answer the questions. Final answer will be given after assignment is due. Additionally, many of the questions will have random numerical input values, hence assignments will be unique to each student.
column2: How many unexcused absences will result in a course grade of F?
column3: More than 4 unexcused absences.

column1: This class is CHEM 140, General Chemistry, taught by Sturgeon in 2023. Your homework grade will be based not only on getting the right answer for the problem, but also on showing a legibly worked-out solutions. This criterion is also true of exams and quizzes (no work shown = no credit.) Therefore, you must keep a homework journal in which you document all of your homework efforts/problems. This must be a separate notebook from your class notes because we may collect the notebooks from time to time. By keeping a journal like this, you will also be able to review problems before exams and quizzes. The homework journals will be checked periodically in lab. It is often useful for students to work together to develop an understanding of the material and therefore, we encourage you to establish study partnerships. However, since homework assignments are graded, final Aktiv responses need to be a result of your independent work. It is best to treat the homework like you are taking a practice exam. Keep in mind that you will not have the book or your study partners help during exams, so make sure that you can independently work problems.
column2: What should I do if I have difficulty with my homework?
column3: Reach out and discuss the material with a study partner or seek help from your teacher.

column1: This class is CHEM 140, General Chemistry, taught by Sturgeon in 2023. QUIZZES: Quizzes may be announced or unannounced. These will be given so that I can monitor your progress and see if you can apply the concepts without the use of your book. Quiz grades will be a part of your overall homework grade. EXAMS: There will be 3 semester exams given during the lecture period (55 mins). The final exam will be held on Friday May 5th at 8:00 am. You will not be allowed to take the final exam early. LABORATORY: As noted above 25% of your grade is earned in the lab. More details will be provided during lab period.  HELP OUTSIDE OF CLASS Supplemental instruction: These problem solving/help sessions will be held in the late afternoons/evenings. These sessions, which are led by a student who have previously taken the class, are not required. However, it is highly recommended that you attend so that you can work on your problem solving skills that are necessary for this class. This session is not for doing homework. See the Supplement Instruction handouts for more information. Your supplemental instruction leader will be announced.
column2: How is the quiz grade incorporated into the student's grade?
column3: The quiz grade is a part of the student's overall homework grade.

column1: This class is CHEM 140, General Chemistry, taught by Sturgeon in 2023. Tutoring: Tutoring is available for all chemistry classes. Stay tuned for details. Student Success at Monmouth College: Student Success & Accessibility Services offers FREE resources to assist Monmouth College students with their academic success. Programs include Supplemental Instruction for some classes, Drop-In and appointment tutoring, and individual Academic Coaching. The office is setup to help all students excel academically, since every student can work toward better grades, practice stronger study skills, and manage their time better.  Accessibility Services: If you have a disability or had academic accommodations in high school or another college, you may be eligible for academic accommodations at Monmouth College under the Americans with Disabilities Act (ADA). Monmouth College is committed to equal educational access. To discuss any of the services offered, please call or meet with Robert Crawley, Interim Director of Student Success & Accessibility Services. SSAS is located in the new ACE space on the first floor of the Hewes Library, opposite Einsteins Bros Bagels. They can be reached at 309-457-2257 or via email at: ssas@monmouthcollege.edu
column2: What services does Student Success & Accessibility Services offer?
column3: Student Success & Accessibility Services offers free resources such as Supplemental Instruction for some classes, Drop-In and appointment tutoring, and individual Academic Coaching.

column1: This class is CHEM 140, General Chemistry, taught by Sturgeon in 2023. ACCOMMODATIONS: If you require accommodations as a result of disability (classroom modifications, adaptive equipment, or alternative testing arrangements) please notify me as soon as possible. Although a disability may be recorded with the College, I take no action unless requested by the student. So, for example, if you require extra time for an exam, you must make the request to the instructor after the first exam is announced and at least two days before the exam is given. ACADEMIC HONESTY: Honesty in ones academic work is of the utmost importance for the maintenance and growth of the individual and of our intellectual community. We therefore require all our students to contribute to this community of learners and to make a vigorous commitment to academic honesty. The above statement was taken from the Scots Guide (https://www.monmouthcollege.edu/offices/student-affairs/student-handbook/). You should be aware that violations of academic honesty could result in punishments up to and including failing the course. Understanding academic honesty is a part of your education and we will discuss it when appropriate. If you have questions concerning academic honesty, please ask.
column2: What must a student do to request accommodations due to a disability?
column3: A student must notify the instructor as soon as possible after the first exam is announced and at least two days before the exam is given.

column1: This class is CHEM 140, General Chemistry, taught by Sturgeon in 2023. ACCOMMODATIONS: If you require accommodations as a result of disability (classroom modifications, adaptive equipment, or alternative testing arrangements) please notify me as soon as possible. Although a disability may be recorded with the College, I take no action unless requested by the student. So, for example, if you require extra time for an exam, you must make the request to the instructor after the first exam is announced and at least two days before the exam is given. ACADEMIC HONESTY: Honesty in ones academic work is of the utmost importance for the maintenance and growth of the individual and of our intellectual community. We therefore require all our students to contribute to this community of learners and to make a vigorous commitment to academic honesty. The above statement was taken from the Scots Guide (https://www.monmouthcollege.edu/offices/student-affairs/student-handbook/). You should be aware that violations of academic honesty could result in punishments up to and including failing the course. Understanding academic honesty is a part of your education and we will discuss it when appropriate. If you have questions concerning academic honesty, please ask.
column2: What does academic honesty involve?
column3: Academic honesty involves contributing to a community of learners and making a commitment to honesty in one's academic work.

column1: This class is CHEM 140, General Chemistry, taught by Sturgeon in 2023. A SUMMARY OF HOW TO SUCCEED IN THIS CLASS: Learning chemistry takes a lot of practice and constant review of the material you have learned in previous weeks. Therefore, you should expect to spend a significant amount of time outside of class learning the material. We expect you to: 1) take careful notes and review them shortly after the class, 2) do the homework, 3) review the answers to the homework when the solutions are posted, 4) review your exams and quizzes, and 5) get help if you dont understand something. COUNSELING SERVICES: Monmouth College provides cost-free, professional and confidential counseling sessions to support you and to help you manage challenges that may impact your personal and academic success. The Counseling Center is located on the upper level of Poling Hall (Rooms 204 and 216) and the hours are Monday-Friday, 8:30 am. to 5:00 pm. For an appointment call Student Success at 309-457-2115, email counselingservices@monmouthcollege.edu , cbeadles@monmouthcollege.edu, or tcaudill@monmouthcollege.edu or request an appointment directly by going to titanium.monmouthcollege.edu and click on request an appointment.
column2: How can I get an appointment with the Counseling Center?
column3: Contact Student Success at 309-457-2115 or email counselingservices@monmouthcollege.edu, cbeadles@monmouthcollege.edu, or tcaudill@monmouthcollege.edu or go to titanium.monmouthcollege.edu and click on request an appointment.
